001package imagingbook.common.color.gamma;
002
003/**
004 * <p>
005 * Defines the "modified gamma correction" used for converting linear to
006 * non-linear color component values. The mapping function consists of a linear
007 * and non-linear part. In the forward mapping ({@link #applyFwd(double)}), the
008 * linear part covers input values between a = 0,...,a0, while values a =
009 * a0,...,1 are mapped non-linearly. For the inverse mapping
010 * ({@link #applyInv(double)}), the linear part is b = 0,...,b0, the non-linear
011 * part is b = b0,...,1. Theoretically all mapping parameters can be derived
012 * from parameters {@code gamma} and {@code a0} (the linear to non-linear
013 * transition point) only. Note that {@code gamma} specifies the nominal &gamma;
014 * parameter for the <em>forward</em> (i.e., linear to non-linear) mapping, e.g.,
015 * &gamma; = 1/2.4 for sRGB. See Sec. 3.7.6 of [1] for more details.
016 * </p>
017 * <p>
018 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
019 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
020 * </p>
021 * 
022 * @author WB
023 * @version 2022/11/14
024 */
025public class ModifiedGammaMapping implements GammaMapping {
026        
027        /** Gamma mapping function instance for ITU-R BT.709 (see Table 3.1 of [1]). */
028        public static ModifiedGammaMapping ITU709 = new ModifiedGammaMapping(1/2.222, 0.018); //, 4.5, 0.099);
029        
030        /** Gamma mapping function instance for sRGB (see Table 3.1 of [1]). 
031         * Note that we need to specify parameters s and d too to comply 
032         * strictly with the sRGB standard. */
033        public static ModifiedGammaMapping sRGB = new ModifiedGammaMapping(1/2.4, 0.0031308, 12.92, 0.055);
034        
035        private final double gamma;
036        private final double igamma;
037        private final double a0;
038        private final double b0;
039        private final double s;
040        private final double d;
041        
042        /**
043         * Constructor, derives parameters s and d from gamma and a0
044         * (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
045         * @param gamma in [0,1], the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping (e.g., gamma = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
046         * @param a0 in [0,1], the linear to non-linear transition point (e.g., a0 = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
047         */
048        public ModifiedGammaMapping(double gamma, double a0) {
049                this(gamma, a0, s(gamma, a0), d(gamma, a0));
050        }
051        
052        /**
053         * Constructor, accepts explicit parameters s and d to allow for
054         * minor inaccuracies in published standards.
055         * 
056         * @param gamma in [0,1], the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping (e.g., gamma = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
057         * @param a0 in [0,1], the linear to non-linear transition point (e.g., a0 = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
058         * @param s &gt; 0, the slope s of the linear section (e.g., s = 12.92 for sRGB)
059         * @param d &ge; 0 the offset d of the non-linear section (e.g., s = 0.055 for sRGB)
060         */
061        public ModifiedGammaMapping(double gamma, double a0, double s, double d) {
062                this.a0 = a0;
063                this.b0 = s * a0;
064                this.gamma = gamma;
065                this.igamma = 1.0 / gamma;
066                this.s = s;
067                this.d = d;
068        }
069
070        /**
071         * Function s(gamma, a0) derives the slope s of the linear section
072         * from parameters gamma and a0 (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
073         * 
074         * @param gamma the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping
075         * @param a0 the linear to non-linear transition point
076         * @return the slope s of the linear section
077         */
078        protected static double s(double gamma, double a0) {
079                return gamma / (a0 * (gamma - 1) + Math.pow(a0, 1 - gamma));
080        }
081        
082        /**
083         * Function d(gamma, a0) derives the offset d of the non-linear section
084         * from parameters gamma and a0 (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
085         *  
086         * @param gamma the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping
087         * @param a0 the linear to non-linear transition point
088         * @return the offset d of the non-linear section
089         */
090        protected static double d(double gamma, double a0) {
091                return 1.0 / (Math.pow(a0, gamma) * (gamma - 1) + 1) - 1;
092        }
093        
094    @Override
095        public double applyFwd(double a) {
096                return (a <= a0) ?
097                        s * a :
098                        (1 + d) * Math.pow(a, gamma) - d;
099    }
100    
101    @Override
102        public double applyInv(double b) {
103        return (b <= b0) ?
104                (b / s) :
105                        Math.pow((b + d) / (1 + d), igamma);
106    }
107    
108    @Override
109        public float applyFwd(float a) {
110                return (float) applyFwd((double) a);
111    }
112    
113    @Override
114        public float applyInv(float b) {
115        return (float) applyInv((double) b);
116    }
117    
118    // -----------------------------------------------
119    
120    /**
121         * Forward Gamma mapping (from linear to non-linear component values).
122         * 
123         * @param A an array of linear component values in [0,1]
124         * @return an array of gamma-corrected (non-linear) component values
125         */
126    public float[] applyFwd(float A[]) {
127        float[] B = new float[A.length];
128        for (int i = 0; i < A.length; i++) {
129                B[i] = applyFwd(A[i]);
130        }
131                return B;
132    }
133    
134    /**
135         * Inverse Gamma mapping (from non-linear to linear component values).
136         * 
137         * @param B an array of non-linear (Gamma-corrected) component value in [0,1]
138         * @return an array of linear component values
139         */
140    public float[] applyInv(float B[]) {
141        float[] A = new float[B.length];
142        for (int i = 0; i < B.length; i++) {
143                A[i] = applyInv(B[i]);
144        }
145                return A;
146    }
147
148}
